OCDS.description: Timeline

OCDS.title: Publish your requirements. This will always show the current date
Clarification period closes
Deadline to publish your responses to the clarification questions
Deadline for suppliers to submit their response
Confirm your the next steps to suppliers
Start suppler evaluation
Supplier presentations (if you have requested this)
Standstill start
OCDS.description:
A 10-day pause in the procedure for suppliers to consider if they wish to challenge the decision. 
 if you do not require a standstill, change this date to be same as point 9 below

OCDS.title: When you plan to award the contract
When you expect to the to be signed
When you expect the supplier to start

nonOCDS.prompt: Instructions

criteria.title: How to bid including evaluation criteria.

OCDS.description: Set the overall weighting between quality and price

OCDS.title: Quality
OCDS.description: Range: 25% to 75%

OCDS.title: Price
OCDS.description: Range: 10% to 75%

nonOCDS.prompt:
You need to set the overall weighting for quality and price according to your requirements. Your total percentage for both must be 100%.
Whatever overall weighting you set for quality, you will then need to split again between the 3 categories (technical, cultural fit and social value) in the next screens.
If you cannot remember what you originally included in your pricing schedule you can read or edit your uploaded file.

OCDS.description: Set the overall weighting for the question categories

OCDS.title: Technical
Cultural
Social value
Price

nonOCDS.prompt: Set the ratio between technical, cultural and social value within quality. The total must not equal 100%

OCDS.description: Write your technical questions

OCDS.title: Enter your question
OCDS.description: Your question should be specific, and detailed. You can add more information, that will help the supplier to answer your questions fully, in the boxes below.

OCDS.title: Enter more details about your question
OCDS.description: Include any details that the supplier might find useful to be able to fully answer your question.

OCDS.title: Explain what good looks like
OCDS.description: Describe the type of answers you would like to see from suppliers. Include anything specific you might need to know.

OCDS.title: Enter a weighting for this question
OCDS.description: You need to enter a weighting for this individual question.

nonOCDS.prompt:
You now need to decide the weighting for each technical question you want to ask. The total weighting for this category must add up to 100%.
>Technical questions are used to evaluate if the supplier can do the work you need, with the skills and experience they have, and show that they understand your project. Suppliers will submit a separate document in answer to each question.
You can add a maximum of 10 questions. The total weighting of all questions in this category must add up to 100%.

OCDS.description: Write your cultural fit questions

OCDS.title: Enter your question
OCDS.description: Your question should be specific, and detailed. You can add more information, that will help the supplier to answer your questions fully, in the boxes below.

OCDS.title: Enter more details about your question
OCDS.description: Include any details that the supplier might find useful to be able to fully answer your question.

OCDS.title: Explain what good looks like
OCDS.description: Describe the type of answers you would like to see from suppliers. Include anything specific you might need to know.

OCDS.title: Enter a weighting for this question
OCDS.description: You need to enter a weighting for this individual question.

nonOCDS.prompt:
You now need to decide the weighting for each cultural fit question you want to ask. The total weighting for this category must add up to 100%.
Cultural fit questions are used to evaluate if the supplier''s organisational values align with your organisation''s. This can help you to decide if you will work well together. Suppliers will submit a separate document in answer to each question.
You can add a maximum of 10 questions. The total weighting of all questions in this category must add up to 100%.

OCDS.description: Write your social value questions

OCDS.title: Your social value question
OCDS.description: Enter another requirement group

OCDS.title: Provide additional detail for your question
Explain what good looks like
OCDS.description: Enter your another requirement

OCDS.title: What weighting do you wish to give this question
OCDS.description: Add another social vue Group Question

nonOCDS.prompt:
Social value questions are used to evaluate if the supplier can provide products or services that will help you to achieve your own organisation''s social value goals.
You will use these questions to evaluate suppliers. Suppliers will submit a separate document in answer to each question.
You can add a maximum of 10 questions.

OCDS.description: Set your scoring criteria

OCDS.title: Select scoring model
OCDS.description: Select the scoring model you want to use

cols: An Excellent comprehensive response that meets the requirements. Indicates an excellent response with detailed supporting evidence and no weaknesses resulting in a high level of confidence.
A Good response that meets the requirements with good supporting evidence. Demonstrates good understanding
Meets the requirements - the response generally meets the requirements, but lacks sufficient detail to warrant a higher mark.
A poor response with reservations. The response lacks convincing detail with risk that the proposal will not be successful in meeting all the requirements.
Failed to provide confidence that the proposal will meet the requirements. An unacceptable response with serious reservations.

The response fully meets all requirement''s with detail provided minimising risks to delivery.
The response is comprehensive and unambiguous, demonstrating a thorough understanding of the requirement''s and provides details of how the requirement will be met in full without additional support from the Contracting Authority, other than outlined within the Statement of Requirements

The response is acceptable and meets all the basic requirement''s. However, the response, is not sufficiently detailed to minimise the risk and/or the proposed approach may require additional support (in addition to that outlined in the Statement of Requirements) from the Contracting Authority to meet its deliverables

The response has met some, but not all elements of the requirement, which poses risk that the proposal will not meet the deliverables required.
The response does not demonstrate a full understanding of the requirement posing major concerns.

The response does not meet any of the requirements or no response has been provided. An unacceptable and/or non-compliant response with serious reservationd, demonstrating no understanding of the requirement.

OCDS.title: Enter the name for this tier
OCDS.description: Add another social value Group Question

OCDS.title: Enter the points for this tier
OCDS.description: Add another social value Group Question

OCDS.title: Enter the description for this tier
OCDS.description: Add another tier

OCDS.description: Learn about adding context and requirements

OCDS.title: Guidance on assessment bases

nonOCDS.prompt: Please read this content to understand how to fill in the following sections on assessment bases

OCDS.description: IR35 acknowledgement

options.value: I need a contracted out service
options.text: You outsource all ownership and responsibility for operational delivery to the supplier, including directing and managing the people delivering the service. You will not need to operate the off-payroll working rules but the supplier may do.

You engage a person or team of people to work with your staff and you manage operational direction and control. The off-payroll working rules can apply to anyone who works through a qualifying intermediary such as their own limited company.

nonOCDS.prompt: Instructions for IR35 requirements

OCDS.description: Terms and acronyms

OCDS.title: Write the term or acronym
OCDS.description: Write the term or acronym

OCDS.title: Write a definition for the term or acronym explaining what it means
OCDS.description: Add another term or acronym

nonOCDS.prompt: Define any terms and acronyms that suppliers may not be familiar with. This will help suppliers to understand what they mean, particularly if you use them in your project background details in the next step.

OCDS.description: Background to your procurement

OCDS.title: Provide details relating to the requirement''s background and the events leading up to the goods/services being required
Include any detail relating to the ''Public Services (Social Value) Act 2012'' which will be applied to secure wider social, economic and environmental benefits

nonOCDS.prompt:
To help suppliers understand what problem you want to solve, you will need to give them more information about what you are looking for, for example:

  • information about your company or the users
  • outcomes you want to achieve
  • the timeframes for completing the work
  • reasons for the change ( for example legal, regulatory or replacing an existing service)
  • any risks or challenges they should be aware of
  • any impacts on the organisation if you do not do the work needed or complete it in the timeframes given

OCDS.description: The business problem you need to solve

OCDS.title: The business problem you need to solve
OCDS.description:
A supplier will need this information so they understand what you want to achieve. You can include:
  • the impact on the organisation if you do not do the work needed
  • the impact if it’s not complete in the timeframes available

nonOCDS.prompt:
A problem statement outlines what the situation is and why it needs to be solved. It can also include what your expected deliverables or outcomes are.

A supplier will need this information so they understand what you want to achieve. You can include:

  • the impact on the organisation if you do not do the work needed
    • li>the impact if it’s not complete in the timeframes available

OCDS.description: The people who will use your product or service

OCDS.title: First service user type
OCDS.description: Give this group a name

nonOCDS.prompt: Provide some information about the types of people who will use the service you want to develop. This could be the general public or more specific user groups, for example, they could be something like car drivers, van drivers and lorry drivers. Give as much information as possible, including if your service users have specific needs.

OCDS.description: Any work that has been Completed so far

OCDS.title: Enter more details about this user type

nonOCDS.prompt: To help suppliers understand what work has been completed prior to the requirements they must fulfil

OCDS.description: Which phase the project is currently in

options.text: You haven''t started any work on the project.

You still need to find out more about the problem that needs to be solved, including who the people who will use your service are and what they need the service to do, as well as any technology or policy constraints.

You have completed the discovery phase and are now testing solutions, usually by building prototypes and carrying out testing with real users. You are not yet in a position to release anything to the public.

You have established your best solution from the alpha phase, and now you are building it for real. At this stage, you are integrating your build with your existing systems and rolling it out to real users.
Your live service needs sustainable support, as well as iterations to improve and evolve.
Service design phases aren''t applicable to your project.

nonOCDS.prompt:
Let suppliers know if any work has been started, and which phase you think the project is in.

Find out more about services design phases.

OCDS.description: Which phase(s) of the project you need resource for

nonOCDS.prompt: Read more about services design phases.

OCDS.description: The expected duration of project

OCDS.title: Enter the date you want the project to start
OCDS.description:
Your project cannot start after:   19 January 2024 
 For example 22 11 2021

OCDS.title: Enter how long you think the project will run for
OCDS.description:
We recommend that your project should not be for longer than 4 years 
 For example 2 years, 4 months, 10 days

OCDS.title: Enter contract extension period
OCDS.description:
You may want to advise the supplier that the project may be extended. This should not exceed 25% of the length of the original project 
 For example 0 years, 6 months, 15 days

nonOCDS.prompt: You need to enter the expected start date and duration so suppliers can confirm they can work to your timelines.

OCDS.description: Who the buying organisation is

OCDS.title: Name of the organisation doing the procurement
Name of the organisation using the products or services that are being procured

nonOCDS.prompt:
Name the organisation who will use the products or services you are buying through this procurement.

Some organisations might procure products and services on behalf of another organisation who then use and pay for what was procured.

OCDS.title: Summaries the outcome of any relevant pre-market engagement

OCDS.title: Choose the option that best describes if this is new, or a replacement or expansion of existing products or services.

nonOCDS.task: Define if the procurement is New, a replacement or expansion
nonOCDS.prompt: Is this for new, replacement or expanded products or services?

OCDS.description: Tell us if there is an existing supplier

options.text: Please enter the name of the incumbent supplier
This is a new project with no existing suppliers providing the products or services.

OCDS.title: Name of incumbent supplier

nonOCDS.prompt: If you are replacing or expanding an existing service, you may already be working with another supplier. Select the most relevant option below.

OCDS.description: Management information and reporting requirements

OCDS.title: Please insert any specific details relating to the provision of management information or reporting by the supplier

nonOCDS.prompt: To help suppliers understand what information they will be expected to supply to you to support your management information and reporting systems

OCDS.title: Publish your RfI
Clarification period ends
Deadline for publishing responses to RfI clarification questions
Deadline for suppliers to submit their RfI response
Confirm your next steps to suppliers

nonOCDS.prompt: Instructions for essential skills

OCDS.description: Define your service levels and KPIs

OCDS.title: Name of requirement
OCDS.description: For example, ''Delivery timescales''

OCDS.title: Description of the criteria
OCDS.description: For example, ''Deliveries should be received within three working days of when the order is placed''.

OCDS.title: Your success target
OCDS.description: For example, ''98%''

nonOCDS.task: Enter your service level requirement / KPI
nonOCDS.prompt:
Provide information about the service levels that you need from the successful supplier. Include any key performance indiciators (KPIs) you have, and make sure the service levels are S.M.A.R.T:

  • specific (clear and unambiguous)
  • measurable (quantifiable)
  • achievable (realistic)
  • relevant (serve the good of the project)
  • time-bound (there are clear timescales and deadlines)

OCDS.description: Add any performance incentives and exit strategies

OCDS.title: Enter details of any performance incentives or expected actions for poor performance:
Give details about any exit strategy that you would apply if a supplier performed poorly, and you needed to end their contract early:

nonOCDS.prompt:
Describe how you will incentivise excellent perfomance and/or expect compensation for poor performance (for example, service credits).

You should also include your exit strategy in the event that the supplier fails to meet your needs and you have to terminate the contract.

OCDS.description: Contract value and how suppliers will meet the project needs within this budget

OCDS.title: Maximum estimated contract value
OCDS.description:
This should include any contract extensions
For example £30000

OCDS.title: Minimum estimated contract value
OCDS.description: For example £10000

nonOCDS.prompt: Set a defined budget for your project so suppliers can explain how they can deliver what you need within the budget you have available.

OCDS.description: Enter your project requirements

OCDS.title: Name of the group
OCDS.description: Enter a name for the group. Make sure its is clear so that the supplier will understand it.

OCDS.title: Name of the requirement
OCDS.description: Enter a clear and simple name for the requirement

OCDS.title: Describe the requirement
OCDS.description: Enter more details about the requirement, including anything you would need the supplier to specifically show.

nonOCDS.prompt:
Enter the requirements of your project that need to be met by the supplier. This could include any accreditations, qualifications or certifications suppliers need to have, or skills or experience that would be useful.
You can sort these requirements into 5 groups, with a maximum of 10 requirements in each group.
